importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The first reported customer incident related to the rearview camera issue occurred on this date, marking the beginning of the data collection period for the recall.
Ford plans to send interim letters to affected vehicle owners on this date, informing them of the recall and the upcoming software update.
The final remedy for the recall—complete software update—is expected to be available by this date, ensuring full resolution of the issue.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Between January 2022 and September 2022, Ford reviewed customer complaints and warranty data, identifying the onset of reported issues with the rearview camera system.
This timeframe covers the implementation of interim fixes and the eventual rollout of the final software update, indicating a multi-year resolution process.

keyTakeAways: Ford is recalling over 290,000 U.S. vehicles from the 2020–2022 F-250 SD, F-350 SD, and F-450 SD models due to potential rearview camera image display failures in certain lighting conditions, which could increase crash risk.
The recall is based on 10 customer reports reviewed by Ford and the NHTSA, with no known accidents or injuries linked to the issue.
Ford will provide a free software update to fix the image processing module issue at dealerships.
Interim letters to owners are scheduled for October 20, 2025, with final letters expected in March 2026.
Vehicle owners can contact Ford customer service at 1-866-436-7332 or the NHTSA hotline at 1-888-327-4236, or visit www.nhtsa.gov for more information.
This recall is relevant to public safety because it addresses a potentially hazardous flaw in a critical safety feature of commercial trucks, which may affect driver visibility and lead to accidents.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Ford is recalling over 290,000 U.S.-sold 2020–2022 F-250 SD, F-350 SD, and F-450 SD trucks due to a potential failure in the rearview camera system’s image display under certain lighting conditions, which could increase crash risk. The recall is based on 10 customer reports reviewed by Ford and the NHTSA, with no known accidents or injuries reported. Ford will provide a free software update to fix the image processing module defect at dealerships. Interim letters to owners are expected on October 20, 2025, with final letters to be issued in March 2026. The issue highlights a critical safety vulnerability in commercial trucks, impacting driver visibility and public road safety.
title: Ford Recalls Over 290,000 Trucks Due to Rearview Camera Display Issues
